metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: You already know that Java supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
content.html: You already know that Java supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

content.text: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.
content.html: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.

content.text: Java has the following conditional statements:
Use the if statement to specify a block of Java code to be executed if a condition is true .
content.html: Use the if statement to specify a block of Java code to be executed if a condition is true.

content.code_html:
if (condition) {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition is true
}

content.text: Note that if is in lowercase letters. Uppercase letters (If or IF) will generate an error.
content.html: Note that if is in lowercase letters. Uppercase letters (If or IF) will generate an error.

content.text: In the example below, we test two values to find out if 20 is greater than 18. If the condition is true , print some text:
content.html: In the example below, we test two values to find out if 20 is greater than 18. If the condition is true, print some text:

content.code_html:
if (20 > 18) {
  System.out.println("20 is greater than 18");
}

content.code_html:
int x = 20;
int y = 18;
if (x > y) {
  System.out.println("x is greater than y");
}

content.text: In the example above we use two variables, x and y , to test whether x is greater than y (using the > operator). As x is 20, and y is 18, and we know that 20 is greater than 18, we print to the screen that "x is greater than y".
content.html: In the example above we use two variables, x and y, to test whether x is greater than y (using the > operator). As x is 20, and y is 18, and we know that 20 is greater than 18, we print to the screen that "x is greater than y".

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following code: int number = 20; if (number > 5) { System.out.println("Greater than 5"); }
content.html:
What will be the result of the following code:
int number = 20;
if (number > 5) {
  System.out.println("Greater than 5");
}
